en_first_half: Mr. John Dashwood had not the strong feelings of the rest of the family; but he was affected by a recommendation of such a nature at such a time, and he promised to do every thing in
en_second_half: his power to make them comfortable. His father was rendered easy by such an assurance, and Mr. John Dashwood had then leisure to consider how much there might prudently be in his power to do for them.
en_results_raw: his power to make both his sisters and his mother comfortable. His father had no apprehension of his not being so; he knew that however he might wish to oblige his wife, he would not be able to afford the expense of visiting them at Norland, as soon as everybody else did, after they had quitted it. It had been settled in the family that Mrs. Dashwood and her daughters were to remove from Sussex in the spring, and take up their residence in Devonshire, a county which offered them a prospect of greater seclusion and a more reasonable rate of living. Mr. Dashwood had given his wife no reason to expect that he would raise any objection to this plan, and as it was one that suited her own convenience, she had not sought to dissuade him from it. But now, as the time drew near for their removal, she began to feel some apprehensions that he might not be so willing to part with them as she had supposed. She knew that he was not a man of strong feelings, but still she had hoped that he would have been more attached to his family than he appeared to be. She was, however, determined to make the best of the situation, and to endeavour to render their new mode of life as comfortable and agreeable as possible. With this view, she set about making the necessary arrangements for their removal, and in a short time everything was in readiness for their departure.

en_first_half: He was not an ill–disposed young man, unless to be rather cold hearted and rather selfish is to be ill–disposed: but he was, in general, well respected; for he conducted himself with propriety in the discharge of his ordinary duties. Had he married a more amiable
en_second_half: woman, he might have been made still more respectable than he was:—he might even have been made amiable himself; for he was very young when he married, and very fond of his wife. But Mrs. John Dashwood was a strong caricature of himself;—more narrow–minded and selfish.
en_results_raw: and affectionate woman, he might have been made a very different character, and been altogether a more respectable and happy man. As it was, he was not altogether a bad husband, but he was not a good one. He was not unkind to his wife, but he was not kind. He was not a tyrant, but he was not a companion. He was not a lover, but he was not a friend. He was simply a man who had married a woman for his own convenience, and who expected her to make him happy, without putting himself to the trouble of making her so. He was a man who thought that a wife was a piece of furniture, a necessary article, but not a living, breathing, feeling being. And so he treated her, not with cruelty, but with indifference. He did not care for her happiness, he did not care for her misery. He did not care for anything that concerned her, except in so far as it concerned himself. And so he lived, and so he died, a selfish, cold-hearted man, who had never known the warmth of love, or the comfort of friendship.

en_first_half: Mrs. Dashwood remained at Norland several months; not from any disinclination to move when the sight of every well known spot ceased to raise the violent emotion which it produced for a while; for when her spirits began to revive, and her mind became capable of some other exertion than that of heightening its affliction by melancholy remembrances, she was impatient to be gone, and
en_second_half: indefatigable in her inquiries for a suitable dwelling in the neighbourhood of Norland; for to remove far from that beloved spot was impossible. But she could hear of no situation that at once answered her notions of comfort and ease, and suited the prudence of her eldest daughter, whose steadier judgment rejected several houses as too large for their income, which her mother would have approved.
en_results_raw: to find a home that would bring her and her daughters comfort and peace. She had always known that their stay at Norland was temporary, and now that the initial shock of her husband's passing had begun to wear off, she felt an increasing sense of urgency to settle into a new routine. The memories of her life with Mr. Dashwood still lingered, but she was determined to create a new sense of normalcy for herself and her girls. As she began to make preparations for their departure, she couldn't help but feel a sense of trepidation about what the future held. Would they be able to find happiness in their new home, or would the pain of their loss continue to haunt them? Despite her reservations, she steeled herself for the challenges ahead, knowing that she had to be strong for the sake of her daughters. With a newfound sense of determination, she set about making the necessary arrangements for their move, her mind focused on the prospect of a brighter future. As the days turned into weeks, the Dashwood women slowly began to pack up their belongings, each item carefully wrapped and placed into trunks, a tangible reminder of the life they were leaving behind. The thought of starting anew was daunting, but Mrs. Dashwood was resolute in her decision to create a better life for herself and her daughters, one that would be filled with love, laughter, and a sense of belonging.

He is also extremely fond of music, and has a great deal of pleasure in listening to it, though he does not play himself. I have often heard him express his admiration of a beautiful sunset, or a fine landscape, and I have no doubt that he would be equally delighted with a beautiful picture, or a fine piece of sculpture. His taste may not be refined, but it is genuine, and I think that is a great deal better than a pretended taste, which is often nothing more than a mere affectation. I have known people who have pretended to be great connoisseurs, and yet have had no real feeling for the arts, but only a desire to appear fashionable and cultivated. I think it is much better to be sincere, and to acknowledge one's own ignorance, than to pretend to be something that one is not. The evocative melodies still lingered in her mind, and the memories associated with them refused to be silenced. She wandered to the window, and gazing out into the night, allowed the tears she had been fighting to fall freely. The stars twinkled above, a celestial showcase of beauty and indifference, a poignant reminder of the vastness of the world and the smallness of her own sorrow. As she stood there, lost in the depths of her grief, the night air carried the faint sound of a horse's hooves, a sound that made her heart skip a beat, a sound that brought with it a glimmer of hope, a hope that was quickly extinguished as the rider passed by, a stranger, not the one she longed to see. The disappointment was crushing, and she turned away from the window, her eyes blinded by tears, her heart heavy with the realization that she might never again experience the joy that music had brought her, the joy that Willoughby's presence had brought her. The night wore on, a long and sleepless night, filled with the echoes of what could never be again, a night that would eventually give way to dawn, but for now, it was a night of sorrow, a night of longing, a night of memories that refused to be forgotten.

en_first_half: Amongst the objects in the scene, they soon discovered an animated one; it was a man on horseback riding towards
en_second_half: them. In a few minutes they could distinguish him to be a gentleman; and in a moment afterwards Marianne rapturously exclaimed,
en_results_raw: them at a slow pace, his face obscured by the shade of a wide-brimmed hat. As he drew closer, the group could see that he was dressed in worn, earth-toned clothing and carried a long, leather satchel slung over his shoulder. The horse, a majestic chestnut mare with a gleaming copper coat, seemed to sense the group's unease and snorted softly, its ears pricked forward in alertness. The rider, however, appeared completely at ease, his movements fluid and relaxed as he guided the horse towards the group with a gentle tug on the reins. As he approached, the group could see that he was a tall, imposing figure with a strong jawline and piercing blue eyes that seemed to bore into their very souls. Despite his rugged appearance, there was an air of quiet authority about him, a sense of calm confidence that commanded attention and inspired a sense of trust. The group watched in silence as he reined in the horse and brought it to a stop before them, his eyes scanning their faces with a piercing intensity that made them feel like they were being sized up and evaluated. After a moment, he nodded to himself, seemingly satisfied with what he saw, and swung down from the saddle with a fluid motion, his movements economical and precise. As he stood before them, the group could see that he was even taller than they had initially thought, his presence seeming to fill the space around him with an aura of quiet power and authority.

Người đàn ông này có vẻ như đang cố gắng tránh sự chú ý, nhưng ba người quan sát vẫn có thể thấy rõ ràng anh ta đang mang theo một gói hàng lớn trên lưng. Họ quyết định theo dõi người đàn ông này để xem anh ta đang làm gì. Khi họ đi theo, họ nhận thấy người đàn ông này dường như đang cố gắng tìm một nơi ẩn náu, và cuối cùng anh ta đã dừng lại tại một ngôi nhà nhỏ nằm sâu trong rừng. Ba người quan sát quyết định chờ đợi và quan sát để xem người đàn ông này sẽ làm gì tiếp theo.
es_first_half: Entre todas las cosas que poblaban el pa isa je, muy pronto descubrieron un objeto animado; era un hombre a caballo,
es_second_half: que venía en dirección hacia ellas. En pocos minutos pudieron apreciar que era un caballero; y un instante después, arrobada, Marianne exclamó:
es_results_raw: que se acercaba lentamente hacia ellos. El hombre llevaba un sombrero de copa y una capa larga que ondeaba al viento, y el caballo parecía cansado pero decidido. A medida que se acercaba, los objetos inanimados del paisaje parecían cobrar vida, como si la presencia del hombre a caballo hubiera despertado algo en ellos. Las rocas se erguían un poco más, las hierbas se estiraban hacia el sol y los árboles susurraban entre sí. El hombre a caballo se detuvo en la cima de una colina y miró a su alrededor, como si estuviera buscando algo o a alguien. Su mirada se posó en los objetos que lo rodeaban, y por un momento, pareció que los estaba viendo de verdad, como si pudiera ver más allá de su apariencia inanimada. Luego, con un suspiro, espoleó a su caballo y continuó su camino, dejando atrás un paisaje que parecía haber cambiado para siempre.

en_second_half: she was vexed and half angry; but resolving to regulate her behaviour to him by the past rather than the present, she avoided every appearance of resentment or displeasure, and treated him as she thought he ought to be treated from the family connection.
en_results_raw: she had never been so thoroughly disappointed in any one in her life. From the moment of his entering the house, she had been convinced that he was very unlike his friend, in disposition and manners; but she had not expected such a total want of cordiality in his behaviour to herself. She had fancied him a very different young man from what he now proved to be; and had been particularly pleased with the idea of his being so well acquainted with Edward, and of their being so much together. But now, instead of being delighted with the prospect of their company, she was only anxious to be rid of them; and to have the house to herself again, that she might indulge in a good cry, and relieve her mind from the painful sensations which their presence had excited. She was vexed with herself for having been so foolish as to expect any thing from him; and still more vexed with him, for not being what she had expected. She was also a little angry with Edward, for having so strongly recommended him to her notice; and for having given her such a favourable opinion of him. But she was most angry with herself, for having been so weak as to allow her expectations to be raised, and her feelings to be interested. She was determined, however, to make the best of the matter, and to endeavour to be as civil and agreeable as possible, though she could not help feeling that it was all a great bore.

La conversación entre Elinor y su visitante continuó de manera forzada, sin que ninguno de los dos lograra encontrar un tema que realmente les interesara. en_results_raw: be seriously vexed by it, and still more so, for being so very ready to resent the presence of a more agreeable companion. She could not help thinking that there was a certain air of studied roughness, a certain awkwardness of manner, which seemed to say, "I am not a man to be trifled with; I am a man of great sense and great importance." But she was not to be intimidated by such airs; she had seen too many of them in her life to be deceived by them now. She watched him, therefore, with great interest, and was not long in discovering that, under all his rough and unpolished exterior, there was a great deal of good sense, and even of good feeling. She saw that he was a man who had been disappointed in life, and that his disappointment had soured his temper; but she also saw that he was a man who was capable of better things, and that, with a little management, he might be brought to show his better side. She determined, therefore, to try her hand at managing him, and to see if she could not bring him to be a little more agreeable, and a little less disagreeable, than he had hitherto shown himself to be.

en_results_raw: disinherit his sister, or is it only the threat of a parent, which, like all threats, will have its effect, and be followed by a reconciliation? I am not aware of any other view that you can reasonably entertain. You know that the connection must be entirely given up, if strict propriety demands it; but I question whether strict propriety is always necessary, and whether it would not be better to sacrifice a little of it for the sake of general happiness. I am not one of those who think that a woman's marrying for money is so very bad, if she marries a man she can love and respect, and who will make her happy. I do not think that a woman is necessarily degraded by marrying a man of inferior rank, if she is fond of him, and he is a good and respectable man. I think that a woman's happiness is of more consequence than her rank, and that she should not be forced to sacrifice her happiness to the pride of her family. I am not saying that I think you should marry Mr. Ferrars, but I do think that you should not be forced to give him up, if you are fond of him, and he is a good and respectable man. I think that you should be allowed to follow your own inclinations, and not be forced to sacrifice your happiness to the pride of your family.

William was quite ready, and in five minutes more the party was walking towards the sea. They took a circuitous route, and by the time they reached the shore, the sun was setting over the sea, casting a golden glow over the waves. The air was filled with the cries of seagulls, and the smell of saltwater and seaweed filled their nostrils. They walked along the beach, enjoying the peaceful atmosphere, and soon came to a small cove, sheltered from the wind and waves. Here they sat down on the sand, and Mary began to tell them about her day, and the people she had met. Her mother listened attentively, and William sat silently, taking in the beauty of the surroundings. As the sun dipped below the horizon, they reluctantly got up to leave, feeling refreshed and invigorated by their walk.

But, I suppose, that is the natural consequence of marriage; and I must learn to think it a good thing, for the sake of my brother's happiness. I am sure, I shall always love him, and wish him well; and I shall try to be as fond of his wife, as I can. But, I must own, I do not feel quite so much interest in her, as I should have done, if she had been more lively and agreeable. en_second_half: Marianne still deeper by treating their disengagement, not as a loss to her of any possible good but as an escape from the worst and most irremediable of all evils, a connection, for life, with an unprincipled man, as a deliverance the most real, a blessing the most important.
en_results_raw: the feelings of her sister, who, though equally shocked and distressed, was more inclined to pity than to blame. She saw the agitation of her sister, and, anxious to prevent any violent outbreak, gently took the letter from her hand, and, after a moment's pause, began to read it aloud. The calm and steady tone in which she read, had a soothing effect on her sister's nerves, and, as she listened, her indignation gradually gave way to a deep and sorrowful regret. "Oh, Jane!" she exclaimed, as her sister finished reading, "how could he be so base, so utterly devoid of honor and principle?" Her sister did not answer, but, with tears in her eyes, handed her the letter, and, turning away, hid her face in her handkerchief. The younger sister, with a heavy heart, took the letter, and, after a moment's hesitation, began to read it again, as if hoping to find some excuse, some palliation, for the conduct of the man she had once loved. But the words seemed to burn into her brain, and, with each perusal, her feelings of anger and resentment grew stronger. She felt as if she had been awakened from a dream, and, with the sudden shock, all her illusions had been shattered. The man she had trusted, the man she had loved, was a villain, a man without honor or conscience, and she was left to pick up the fragments of her broken heart.

They were both equally silent, and equally lost in their own reflections, till the arrival of the carriage, which made Elinor start, and Mrs. Jennings rise to lead the way to the door. Marianne, who had only been waiting for their ready signal to take leave, was already in the passage, and with one look at her sister, who was still in her chair, she hastily went out.

en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

es_first_half: —Ahora puede ver cómo es su carácter: derrochador, licencioso, y peor aún que eso. Sabiéndolo, como yo lo he sabido desde hace ya muchas semanas, imagínese lo que debo haber sentido al ver a su hermana tan afecta a él como siempre, y cuando se me aseguró que iba a casarse con él; imagínese lo que habré sentido pensando en todas ustedes. Cuando vine a verla la semana pasada y la encontré sola, estaba decidido a saber la verdad, aunque aún indeciso en cuanto a qué hacer cuando la supiera. Mi comportamiento debe haberle extrañado, pero ahora lo entenderá. Tener que verlas a todas ustedes engañadas en esa forma; ver a su hermana... pero, ¿qué podía hacer? No tenía esperanza alguna de intervenir con éxito; y en ocasiones pensaba que su hermana aún podía mantener suficiente influencia sobre él para recuperarlo. Pero tras un trato tan ignominioso, ¿quién sabe cuáles serían sus intenciones hacia ella? Cualesquiera hayan sido, sin embargo, puede que ahora ella se sienta agradecida de su situación, y sin duda más adelante lo estará, cuando la compare con la de mi pobre Eliza, cuando
es_second_half: piense en la situación miserable y desesperada de esta pobre niña y se la imagine con un afecto tan fuerte por él, tan fuerte como el que ella misma le tiene, y con un espíritu atormentado por las autorrecriminaciones, que la acompañarán durante toda su vida. Con toda seguridad esta comparación le servirá de algo. Sentirá que sus propios sufrimientos no son nada. No provienen de una mala conducta y no pueden traerle desgracia. Al contrario, deberán hacer que en cada uno de sus amigos aumente la amistad hacia ella. La preocupación por su desdicha y el respeto por la entereza que subyace a ella deberán reforzar todos los afectos. Utilice, sin embargo, su propia discreción para comunicarle lo que le he contado. Usted debe saber mejor qué efecto tendrá; y si no hubiera creído muy seriamente y desde el fondo de mi corazón que pudiera serle de alguna utilidad, que pudiera aliviar sus padecimientos, no me habría permitido perturbarla con este relato de las aflicciones que ha debido sufrir mi familia, una narración con la cual podría sospecharse que intento enaltecerme a costa de los demás.
es_results_raw: sepa la verdad sobre su hermano. La pobre Eliza, que siempre fue tan amable y bondadosa, ha sido víctima de su engaño y su falta de escrúpulos. Me duele recordar cómo la trató, cómo la engañó y la abandonó sin miramientos. Y todo esto, ¿para qué? Para satisfacer sus propios deseos y caprichos, sin importarle el daño que causara a los demás.  Pero no solo Eliza ha sido víctima de su comportamiento. Todas ustedes han sido engañadas de alguna manera, han sido objeto de su manipulación y su falta de consideración. Y yo, que he sido testigo de todo esto, me siento responsable de no haber podido hacer nada para evitarlo. Me siento culpable por no haber hablado antes, por no haber advertido a su hermana sobre el carácter de su prometido.  Pero ahora que la verdad ha salido a la luz, espero que su hermana pueda encontrar la fuerza para superar este golpe. Espero que pueda ver que se ha librado de un hombre que no la merecía, que no la amaba de verdad. Y espero que todas ustedes puedan encontrar la paz y la felicidad que se merecen, lejos de la influencia negativa de su hermano.  Me doy cuenta de que mi intervención puede haber causado un gran escándalo, pero no podía quedarme callado. Tenía que hablar, tenía que advertir a su hermana sobre el peligro que corría. Y aunque pueda haber causado un gran dolor y confusión, espero que en el futuro puedan entender mi motivación y perdonarme por mi intervención.  En cuanto a su hermano, no tengo nada más que decir. Su comportamiento habla por sí solo, y no necesito agregar nada más. Solo espero que pueda reflexionar sobre sus acciones y cambiar su comportamiento en el futuro. Pero hasta que eso suceda, no puedo sino sentir lástima por él, por la persona que ha llegado a ser.  En fin, solo quiero decir que estoy aquí para apoyar a su hermana y a todas ustedes en este momento difícil. Estoy aquí para ofrecer mi ayuda y mi consuelo, y espero que puedan aceptarlo. Juntos, podemos superar este obstáculo y encontrar la felicidad y la paz que se merecen.

Geçen hafta gelip de sizi yalnız bulduğum zaman gerçeği öğrenmeye kararlı gelmiştim, gerçi öğrendiğim zaman ne yapacağım konusunda kararsızdım. O zaman davranışım size garip görünmüş olmalı; ama şimdi anlıyorsunuz. Hepinizin böyle aldatıldığını görmek, kızkardeşinizin -ama ne yapabilirdim? Müdahale ederek başarı kazanma umudum yoktu; bazen kızkardeşinizin gücü onu yola getirebilir diye düşünüyordum. Ama şimdi, böyle bir suistimalden sonra, onunla ilgili planlarının ne olduğunu kim söyleyebilir? Onun planlan her ne idiyse, kızkardeşiniz artık kendi durumuna şükran duygusu içinde bakabilip ki şüphesiz bakacaktır, kendi durumunu benim zavallı
tr_second_half: Eliza’mla karşılaştırınca, ona en az kendisi kadar güçlü bir sevgi duymuş bu zavallı kızın hayatı boyunca içinden çıkmayacak pişmanlığın işkencesi içindeki sefil ve umutsuz halini gözünde canlandırınca. en_second_half: that by requiring her longer continuance in London it deprived her of the only possible alleviation of her wretchedness, the personal sympathy of her mother, and doomed her to such society and such scenes as must prevent her ever knowing a moment's rest.
en_results_raw: that it was a decision which would bring her none of the comfort or peace of mind she so desperately sought. As she stood there, trying to come to terms with her mother's words, Marianne couldn't help but feel a sense of disillusionment wash over her. She had always trusted her mother's judgment, but now she found herself questioning it, wondering if she had been blind to follow it so implicitly. The more she thought about it, the more she realized that her mother's opinion was not only misguided but also influenced by her own biases and prejudices. Marianne felt a surge of frustration and disappointment, knowing that she would have to navigate this difficult situation on her own, without the guidance and support she had once taken for granted. As she stood there, lost in thought, Marianne knew that she had to find a way to reconcile her own desires and aspirations with the expectations of those around her, and it was a daunting task that lay ahead.

Cô quyết định dành một chút thời gian để suy ngẫm và tìm kiếm lời khuyên từ những người xung quanh, hy vọng sẽ tìm được hướng đi đúng đắn. I was not, however, to be deterred by this. She received me with a slight inclination of the head, and a faint smile, but she did not offer me her hand, and I was left to infer that she did not wish to encourage my advances. I was not, however, to be discouraged by this. I was determined to make her acquaintance, and to learn more of her character, and I accordingly entered into conversation with her, and endeavored to draw her out. She was, however, not very communicative, and I found it difficult to make any progress with her. I was, however, not to be baulked in my curiosity, and I continued to press her with questions, and to endeavor to draw her into conversation. 'You misunderstand the matter entirely, my dear Elinor,' was his answer. 'I only meant to explain the motives of my actions, and I must confess I should not have offered the living to Edward, if I had not believed there was no chance of his obtaining that which was the object of his desires. But with regard to myself, I must declare there never was a time when I so well understood the value of a single life, and that I never had a greater wish to be married than I have now.' Elinor could not help smiling at the quiet, determined manner in which he made this declaration; but her attention was soon called to her sister, who was not so well pleased with what she heard. Marianne's countenance was expressive of true surprise and vexation. She had not expected that Colonel Brandon would so soon, and so openly, declare himself her admirer; and his words, on the subject of Edward, had given her a new reason for believing that he was not so unhappy as she had imagined. She was silent, however, and did not oppose her sister's wishes. The subject was not again mentioned, and the evening passed away without any further conversation on the matter.

en_first_half: "Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her. The merest awkward country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.— I remember her perfectly. Just the kind of girl I should suppose likely to captivate poor Edward. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the
en_second_half: breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier—I think it is most probable—that something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;—that is certain; absolutely starved."
en_results_raw: unfortunate affair took place; so that I had not, indeed, the power of preventing it. Edward's love for her must have originated in this visit, I suppose; and his preference of her, at this particular time, is but too plainly explained. His increasing melancholy; his thoughts of marrying for connexion; his general indifference to her—is it not the natural result of her behaviour to him? If he can think her so an object as to be in love with, there must be something more in her then I can perceive; certainly, I have had little opportunity of studying her, and therefore will not dispute about her looks, but the sweetness of her temper must have been the great danger. She has one very great security, however, for her heart, which to be sure should be the first consideration. Her want of personal attractions, and the probable heaviness of her figure in a few more years, will always stand in the way of any man of sense and taste, and will, I dare say, secure her from any farther attempts. I am rather surprised that there is not more mark of disdain in his behaviour to her; but I suppose the influence of the lady too much at home to be perceived here. I would not have the idea of the connexion to get abroad, on any account, and should be very much displeased if Lord or Lady Courtland were to know that we suspect it; but between ourselves, I must think it would be the better for him to get the better of it, and I could almost wish that something might come in the way to prevent the marriage.
